p: In Taiwan, there have been reports of local dengue outbreaks caused by different serotypes and genotypes of DENV as well as by the cocirculation of more than one DENV serotype at any given time ( 43 â€“ 46). The Centers for Disease Control of Taiwan confirmed 15,732 cases of dengue fever in 2014 and 43,784 cases in 2015 (largely in southern Taiwan). DENV1 was the predominant strain in 2014 and persisted until 2015, whereupon DENV2 became the predominant strain. A larger number of deaths than in any other previous outbreak resulted from dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome during the 2015 epidemic ( 47). Taiwan is located in a subtropical region, which is ideally suited to the spread of different DENV serotypes brought in by travelers returning from regions in tropical Southeast Asia where dengue is endemic. Indeed, this situation has already occurred, as manifested by the presence of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes in the southern part of the island ( 45, 48).
